reviewText: Vocaloid Hatsune Miku ver. 3e will be available soon, with all-in-one package. Now you can ask her singing for you. [...] About details of Miku Hatsune and the band, please refer to the reviews on Miku Hatsune/Blu-ray MIKUNOPOLIS in LOS ANGELES -Hajimemashite Hatsune Miku desu- [Japan Import]. This time, they performed 30 tunes and duration is nearly 2 hours. No bonus track, but it's enough. Different angles are available on a few tracks. Additional commentary is subtitled and that is only in Japanese. No audio commentary. I recommend you to write SEGA a request of releasing US version of this disc with English subtitles. I believe it's worth to do. Price is high (price is approx. $80 in Japan and street price is a bit lower). My conclusion is the same as on my previous review: the concert still is the showcase of the pop music what we love to listen to. Atmosphere is more "concert" than "festival", not fanatic like in Hatsune Miku - Miku No Hi Kansyasai 39's Giving Day (Blu-ray) [Limited Edition]. I prefer the older one for the atmosphere but I'm also sure that the older one is not for everyone. My top recommendation for US listeners is Miku Hatsune/Blu-ray MIKUNOPOLIS in LOS ANGELES -Hajimemashite Hatsune Miku desu- [Japan Import]. This time the performance of the band (incl. wind section) sounded on my ear like a sophisticated versions of mid '80's - early '90's Japanese pop music. I'm very happy to know that a tradition of Japanese pop is still in a good shape. Mixdown seemed to be optimized for 5.1-channel. Conventional 2-track mix sounded "lighter" than that of Mikunopolis disc. It doesn't matter for those who installed a home-theater system, but it does matter for me since I usually listen to Blu-ray contents with my iPod (in AIFF, no mp3 compression, of course).
